items.title: Canada to announce its women's Olympic hockey team for 2026 Games
Flu surge adding to ER strain, doctors say
items.summary_auto: Some emergency departments across Canada report that the rapid spread of influenza has contributed to overcrowding, as some children and adults face long-lasting fevers, with the latest federal report showing a slight declining picture of flu activity across the country.

items.title: Canada now approves far fewer Jordan’s Principle education requests in Ontario, tribunal hears
items.summary_auto: The federal government has drastically cut funding for First Nations kids in Ontario seeking educational support under Jordan’s Principle, a tribunal hearing revealed this week. The money decreased from $122.1 million to just $1.2 million over the same time periods in 2024 versus 2025.

items.title: Musk's xAI adds new restrictions to Grok after uproar over sexual images
items.summary_auto: Elon Musk's startup xAI has put some restrictions on the image generation function of its Grok chatbot on social media platform X, after the tool's use of AI to create and publish sexualized images sparked a widespread backlash.

items.title: 3 missing amid bushfires, 'catastrophic' conditions in Australia
items.summary_auto: Three people were unaccounted for as out-of-control bushfires raged in the Australian state of Victoria, destroying homes and burning through vast swathes of bushland amid the worst fire conditions since 2019's Black Summer.

items.title: Minneapolis, Portland shootings spur protests over ICE crackdowns as outcry grows
items.summary_auto: Another round of protests were planned for Friday in Minneapolis over the killing of a local woman by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officer during the Trump administration's latest crackdown on a major city, a day after federal immigration officers shot and wounded two people in Portland, Ore.

items.title: Ayatollah, state media rail against 'terrorist agents' amid Iran protests
Another murder prosecution falls apart and frees accused, this time in bounty killings of 2 brothers
items.summary_auto: For the second time in his life a first-degree murder case against an Ottawa man has collapsed before he ever got to trial because of problems in the management of the prosecution against him.

items.title: Lawsuit dismissed in case of Alberta boy injured in toy dinosaur 'swatting match'
items.summary_auto: An Alberta judge has dismissed a lawsuit involving one child suing another after a disagreement over a toy dinosaur led to a finger injury.

items.title: U.S. seizes Olina tanker in Caribbean, 5th vessel taken in Venezuela blockade
items.summary_auto: The U.S. has seized the Olina tanker in the Caribbean, the fifth vessel targeted in recent weeks as Washington steps up efforts to curb Venezuelan oil exports, U.S. officials said on Friday.

items.title: Canadian economy added 8,200 jobs in December, while unemployment rose to 6.8%
items.summary_auto: The results come after three months of strong gains from September to November. The unemployment rate rose to 6.8 per cent in December, up from 6.5 per cent in November.

items.title: Now the veteran, Moh Ahmed to lead young Canadian runners into cross-country worlds
items.summary_auto: Moh Ahmed of St. Catharines, Ont., who has starred on the track for years and ran to his first Canadian cross-country title in November, will lead the national team at his fourth world championship on Saturday in Tallahassee, Fla.

items.title: Iran demonstrations against regime continue as ayatollah, state media rail against 'terrorist agents'
items.summary_auto: Iran signalled on Friday that security forces would crack down on protesters, directly challenging U.S. President Donald Trump's pledge to support those peacefully demonstrating, as the death toll rose to at least 62.

items.title: Russia fires Oreshnik hypersonic missile, with attacks on Ukraine killing at least 4
items.summary_auto: Russia bombarded Ukraine with hundreds of drones and dozens of missiles in a large-scale overnight attack, officials said Friday, killing at least four people. For only the second time, it used a new ballistic missile that it says flies at 10 times the speed of sound and is unstoppable.

items.title: Physicians call on Alberta to declare state of emergency over crowded hospitals
Winnipeg police officer convicted of trafficking would often 'fairy dust' partiers with drugs: former friend
items.summary_auto: A former acquaintance of Elston Bostock says the disgraced Winnipeg police constable had a reputation for being a "hookup" over a period of years, and would routinely "fairy dust" partiers with white powdered drugs.

items.title: Fireguards to protect residents also a boon to Alberta wildlife
items.summary_auto: Bow Valley's bears, birds and elk enjoy new food and open spaces when trees get cleared for fire protection.

items.title: Freeland resignation shakes up already fluid situation in House of Commons
items.summary_auto: Former cabinet minister Chrystia Freeland is officially vacating her seat in the House of Commons on Friday, leaving the Liberal government — which is within striking distance of a majority — one MP down for the time being.

items.title: The Plague isn't a new Lord of the Flies. It's more terrifying
items.summary_auto: The Plague, a new horror-flecked film starring Joel Edgerton and newcomer Everett Blunck, tells the story of a 2000s-era water polo camp. The results are bleak, horrifying and masterful.

items.title: Retired CBC host Cathy Alex remembered for her sense of humour, passion for journalism
items.summary_auto: Former CBC host Cathy Alex, who died this week at 62, is being remembered for her resounding laughter, love of the outdoors and commitment to the communities she served during her 33-year career. Here's what former colleagues shared about their time working with Alex in Thunder Bay, Ont.

items.title: Soaring renovation costs in Quebec force homeowners to rethink how they build, budget
items.summary_auto: Statistics show renovation costs in Quebec have grown dramatically since the pandemic, forcing many homeowners to rethink budgets and timelines.

items.title: Rogers program to reduce youth screen time is a good first step, say parents and experts
items.summary_auto: A new $50 million program to tackle excess screen time for tweens and teens is a good first step, say parents and experts, though they want more action from tech, telecom companies and governments to tackle the problem.

items.title: How Trump and Vance's accounts of Minneapolis ICE shooting differ from video evidence
items.summary_auto: The official White House narrative of what lead a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent to shoot and kill a U.S. citizen in her vehicle in Minneapolis is bumping up hard against what can be seen in videos of the incident.

items.title: French-U.K. Starlink rival pitches Canada on 'sovereign' satellite service for Arctic military operations
items.summary_auto: Eutelsat, a company largely owned by the French and U.K. governments, is offering Canada an alternative to Elon Musk's Starlink satellite broadband communications in the Far North. The company says it can create secure channels that cannot be disconnected for "political" reasons.

items.title: How Louise Penny built the most loyal fan club in Canadian literature
items.summary_auto: Canadian author Louise Penny has created a dedicated community of readers, posting in busy Facebook groups, attending live events and even traveling on literary pilgrimages to the Eastern Townships in Quebec to see the spots that inspired her work.

items.title: Alberta needs to call state of emergency over crowded hospitals, physicians say
items.summary_auto: Dr. Paul Parks, the president-elect of the section of emergency medicine of the Alberta Medical Association, said he is calling for drastic action from the provincial government at the urging of physicians from across the province and across hospital divisions.

items.title: Court records detail prior incident involving ICE officer who shot and killed Minneapolis woman
items.summary_auto: Further information emerged Thursday about the U.S. Customs and Immigration Enforcement officer who allegedly shot and killed a woman inside her vehicle in Minneapolis. The information was revealed after federal officials shared details about the ICE officer that closely those in court documents from another incident in June.
